It's a fair bet that the Japanese yen will fall fairly quickly over the next three months so you may as well go to Japan on vacation at Easter. If so, I thoroughly recommend that you take the airport express at IFC. It's very easy. Once you're at the IFC exit where you can head straight for Queen's Road Central, enter IFC, go past the escalator in front of you and keep walking until you come to another escalator. Go down it, turn left and go straight ahead. It's there. If you wanna travel to Shinjuku from Tokyo station, go through the gate, go down the escalator and look at the signs. You'll see which side is bound for Shinjuku. If you wanna have a coffee at J.Cafe, take the elevator to level four, go straight down the path and go past several shops until you come to an intersection. Turn right and it's there. If you wanna take the elevator to a higher floor, turn left at the intersection, pass several shop until you see Pure Fitness on your left, enter Pure Fitness and the lift is there. I enjoy visiting the annual winter carnival where I go on the roller coasters and ear sushi, sosking up the nice christmassy atmosphere. The sunlight has been dazzlingly hot so you might just as well have a good long soak in an outdoor onsen, soaking up the sun. In fact, I've just got out of an onsen and am drying myself off. However, if you ask me whether Australia is a great place to vacation in, don't bet on it. There's nothing worth doing there. I like Japanese culture and food. I even took the JLPT at N one level. My reading far outshines my speaking so the marks I lost in speaking were offset by those I gained in reading. My friend too took the test. She's a little weak in listening but strong in writing so the marks she gained in the writing part offset the marks she lost in the listening section. After the test, we spent money on clothes and shoes like it was going out of fashion. We entered a casino and gambled like it was going out of fashion. If you enjoy being in Japan, you might spend money on food and cosmetic products like it's going out of fashion. If you go to a casino, you might gamble like it's going out of fashion like we did.
I've just got out of an onsen, towered off and am getting dressed.
I've just got out of a jacuzzi, dried myself off and am dressing.

It's a good bet that you go to Tokyo on vacation during the Easter holiday since the Japanese yen has dropped significantly in the past four months. If so, I heartily recommend you should take the airport express at IFC. It's very easy. Once you're at the IFC exit where you can head straight to Queen's Road Central, enter IFC, pass the escalator in front if you and keep walking until you come to another escalator. Go down the escalator, turn left and go straight ahead. It's there. If you wanna go to Shinjuku from Tokyo Station, go through the gate, go down the escalator and look at the signs. You'll see which side is bound for Shinjuku. If you wanna have a coffee in J.Cafe, take the elevator to level three, go straight down the path and pass several shops until you come to the intersection. Turn right and it's there. If you wanna take a lift to a higher floor, turn left at the intersection, go past several shops until you see Pure Fitness on your left, enter Pure Fitness and the elevator is there. I enjoy visiting the annual winter carnival in Tokyo where I eat sushi and ride the roller coasters, soaking up the nice Christmassy atmosphere. The sun has been dazzlingly bright so you might just as well go for a good long soak in an outdoor onsen, soaking up the sun. In fact, I've just got out of an onsen, dried myself on a towel and am getting dressed. However, if you ask me if Australia is a great place to go for your holidays, I wouldn't bet on it. There's nothing worth doing there. I like Japanese culture and food. I even took the JLPT at N two level. My reading far outshines my writing so the marks I gained in reading offset those I lost in writing. My friend took the test too. He's a little weak on listening but strong on speaking so the marks he lost in the listening part were offset by the marks he gained in the speaking section. After the test, we spent money on shoes and clothes like it was going out of fashion. We went to the casino and gambled like it was going out of fashion. If you enjoy being in Japan, you might spend money on food and cosmetic products like it's going out of fashion. If you enter a casino, you might gamble like it's going out of fashion like we did.

replies.msg: It's a good bet that the Japanese yen will continue falling over the next four months so you might as well go to Japan on vacation over the Easter holiday. If so, I heartily recommend you take the airport express at IFC. It's very easy. Once you're at the IFC exit where you can head straight for Queen's Road Central, enter IFC, pass the escalator in front of you and keep walking until you come to another escalator. Go down it, turn left and go straight ahead. It's there. If you wanna travel to Shinjuku from Tokyo station, go through the gate, go down the escalator and look at the signs. You'll see which side is bound for Shinjuku. If you wanna have a coffee at J.Cafe, take the elevator to level yhree, go down the path and go past several shops until you come to an intersection. Turn right and It's there. If you wanna take the lift to a higher floor, turn left at the intersection, pass several shops until you see Pure Fitness on your left, enter Pure Fitness and the elevator is there. However, if you ask me whether Australia is a good place to vacation in, I wouldn't bet on it. There's nothing worth doing there. I enjoy visiting the annual winter carnival in Tokyo where I go on the roller coasters and eat pancakes, soaking up the nice Christmassy atmosphere. The sun has been dazzlingly bright so you may just as well have a good long soak in an outdoor onsen, soaking up the sun. In fact, I've just got out of an onsen and am toweling off. I like Japanese culture and food. I even took the JLPT at N two level. My reading far outshines my listening so the marks I lost in listening were offset by the marks I gained in reading. My friend took the test too. He's a little weak on writing but strong on speaking so the marks he gained in the speaking part offset those he lost in the writing section. After the test, we spent money on shoes and clothes like it was going out of fashion. We entered a casino and gambled like it was going out of fashion. If you enjoy being in Japan, you might spend money on food and cosmetic products like it's going out of fashion. If you go to a casino, you might gamble like it's going out of fashion like we did.

replies.msg: It's a safe bet that you go to Japan on vacation at Easter since the Japanese yen has fallen quickly over the last four months. If so, I highly recommend you take the airport express at IFC. It's very easy. Once you're at the IFC exit where you can head straight for Queen's Road Central, enter IFC. Pass the escalator in front of you and keep walking until you come to another escalator. Go down it, turn left and go straight ahead. It's there. If you wanna travel to Shinjuku from Tokyo station, go through the gate, go down the escalator and look at the signs. You'll see which side is bound for Shinjuku. If you wanna have a coffee at J.Cafe, take the elevator to level three, go straight down the road and go past several shops until you come to an intersection. Turn right and It's there. If you wanna take a lift to a higher floor, turn left at the intersection, pass several shops until you see Pure Fitness on your left, enter Pure Fitness and the elevator is there. I enjoy visiting the annual winter carnival where I ride the roller coasters and eat sushi, soaking up the nice Christmassy atmosphere. The sunlight has been dazzlingly bright so you might just as well have a good long soak in an outdoor onsen, soaking up the sun. In fact, I've just got out of an onsen, dried myself on a towel and am getting dressed. However, if you ask me whether Australia is a good place to vacation in, don't bet on it. There's nothing worth doing there. I like Japanese culture and food. I even took the JLPT at N one level. My listening far outshines my writing so the marks I lost in writing were offset by the marks I gained in listening. My friend too took the test. She's a little weak on reading but strong on speaking so the marks she gained in the speaking part offset those she lost in the reading section. After the test, we spent money on clothes and shoes like it was going out of fashion. We entered a casino and gambled like it was going out of fashion. If you enjoy being in Japan, you might spend money on food and cosmetic products like it's going out of fashion. If you go to a casino, you might gamble like it's going out of fashion like we did.
I've just got out of a jacuzzi and am toweling off.
I've just got out of a jacuzzi, dried myself off and am dressing.
I've just got out of an onsen, toweled off and am getting dressed.

replies.msg: It is recommended that you read "Tortoises and Turtles" at leisure. It's a fascinating guide to tortoises and turtles written by Agnes Dion, Agnes Ferguson, Agnes Skovbye, Tiera Dion, Celine Ferguson, Craig Gordon-Levitt, Joseph Bernstein, Leonard Gomez, Selena Lipa, Dua Ashkenazy, Eleanor Lipa, Eleanor Bernstein, Tito Riley, Jeremy Dion, Isaac Jones, James Riley, Agnes Jones, Deborah Ashkenazy, Zooey Gomez, Christina Deschanel, Scarlett Aguilera, Agnes Johansson, Deborah Aguilera, Deborah Johansson, Scarlett Grace Moretz, Chloe Johansson, Leonardo Riley, Isaac DiCaprio, Scarlett da Vinci, Avril Dion, Susannah Lavigne, Tito Ashkenazy, Vladimir Gomez, Agnes Lavigne, Deborah Lavigne, Vladimir Bernstein, Margaret Ashkenazy, Margot Grace Moretz, Seven-Eleven and the property developer.

I've vacationed in many countries. I had always thought that many other countries were better than Hong Kong but after I went to these countries on vacation, I realized that in terms of city life, night life, food and shopping, Hong Kong really is the best. In Europe, shops close at four on weekdays and don't open on weekends except for big cities like London in which shops close at six on weekdays and four on the weekends. Their main sorts of entertainment are pubs and clubs. Las Vegas has magnificent night views but it was primarily built for tourism. It's famous for gambling, unique hotel design and shows like boxing events. However, in terms of scenery, Scandinavia and Tibet are the most ravishing I would say. Tibet is famous for its breathtaking scenery at high altitude. Xinjiang is also a place of outstanding scenic beauty. If you think you might have altitude sickness, I suggest that you should bring some medicine along. Besides, my friend who's been to the Mount Everest base camp showed me her photos taken there by which I was awestruck. It's certainly a glamorous vacation destination. A tour of the Mount Everest badd cam would be a once in a lifetime experience. Tibet is also the best place for stargazing I would say since it's much closer to the heavens than any other places on earth and the sky at night is often clear and cloudless. It has some of the highest lakes in the world which are rich with fish and other marine life and the surrounding countryside is inhabited by flocks of yellow ducks and wild horses as well as donkeys. The lakes in Tibet such as Lake Paiku which is four thousand five hundred and ninety two meters above sea level, reflect the beauty of the stars, giving a double view of the sky at night. You can even pitch camp there to get the best view of the stars and the Milky Way galaxy.

I find the Japanese culture very different than the Chinese culture. We enjoy yum cha while they enjoy drinking green tea at bars, soaking up the atmosphere rather than at home. My Japanese friend Agnes is an Aquarius whereas her boyfriend is a Taurus. She's faithful to him and would never cheat on him. When she broke up with her ex, she was driven over the edge. Even when a stranger talked to her, there was an edge of hostility to her voice. But as soon as she had a new relationship target, it took the edge of her emotional upset. Her ex is a swimming champion who easily outshines us in any swimming styles. He's tall and lean who definitely has the edge over lots of swimmers. Recently, her boyfriend got into a scuffle with a guy who was hitting on her. The police showed up later and assigned jealousy as the motive for the scuffle. Last Tuesday, they dined in a restaurant in a hotel which is midway between the supermarket and her place. They lined up outside the restaurant for almost an hour. The line was so big that it stretched from the counter through the lobby area and out the main entrance of the hotel. A stout guy tried to cut in line but was caught. Last Thursday, we met at a midway point between her place and mine then she took me to the shuttle bus bound for her place. A group of people was in the way so she said "Excuse me." The queue was so huge, stretching down the road to the furthest minibus stop. We stood in line for half an hour until three shuttle buses came along at once. Meanwhile, some people mistook this long line for the line for other places. A couple came up to us and asked "Are you in the queue for The Cullunan?" as they wanna be sure that it's the right queue. A burly man pushed in at the head of the line. Later, a svelte woman jumped the line. The slim man behind her said "Excuse me. The end of the line is back there." A petite woman stood beside a slender guy who was midway through the line. While pretending to look at her phone, she edged furtively behind him who didn't realize she was there. Some people might have noticed it but ignored it. Agnes seemed on edge. It turns out she has a job interview next week. Never has she felt so on edge before an interview. Agnes is currently a head chef at a five-star hotel and feels she's found her niche. Her elder brother has also found his niche as a professor, having worked as a researcher for three years. She sometimes has a doze at lunchtime because she has so much work to do that she feels drained. She usually snoozes on the sofa by the fireplace or at his desk when everyone else's eating lunch outside. She once brought her work along to the library where she dozed off at the table. Taking a nap especially in front of the fire is a marvelous way to replenish your energy though. Her eldest brother has just completed his PhD at Peking University and is on the way to becoming a professor. China is on the way to becoming the world's strongest economy. Her elder sister is robust and healthy. ahe does a lot of strength and conditioning exercises in her robust sneakers. After her gym sessions, she usually drinks a cup of robust coffee and a glass of robust wine. She lives in Japan where the economy and the political system are robust. Her younger sister has opened an antique shop which made a great impression on me. There's an exquisite antique which engages my attention. I bet you that the store engages lots of passers-by. I formed a favorable impression of the store. Agnes' auntie has recently passed away at the age of ninety nine. I send my sincere condolences to her aunties family. Agnes' friend Leonardo said "My condolences on the loss of your auntie." Her mom also offered her condolences to her family. Her dad wrote "Our condolences go to her family." Agnes hadn't heard from her cousin for years until last Sunday when she received a call from him. They chatted in exquisite delight.

replies.msg: Her cousin told her that there was a bully in his class so Agnes told him not to engage with him. Just stay out of his way as much as possible. Agnes lives in the most exclusive and expensive area in Tokyo and owns many houses. Unlike Floyd, she's never ostentatious though extremely wealthy. You can find out how ostentatious Floyd's lifestyle is on YouTube, such as his house and car collections. He always wears ostentatious jewelry, such as gold necklaces, rings and bracelets. He loves driving flashy cars and wearing flashy clothes. Do you remember the incident in Langham Place where the escalator stopped and reversed direction at a speed three times as fast as normal, causing people to fall and pile up at the base of the escalator? People were screaming as they tumbled down the escalator. Some people managed to grab the handrail and steady themselves. The incident occasioned a good deal of worry. When you were in secondary school, were there any subjects which you weren't interested in so you didn't engage much during the classes? I remember I didn't really engage in geography classes. I was often daydreaming. Today, many children learn piano, violin, painting, dancing, judo and Japanese. I honestly don't know how they juggle these activities and schoolwork. Some of their parents have to go to work so they find it hard to juggle a career with children. Perhaps they wanna kindle their kids' interest and see which one they have a talent for or can cultivate an interest in. Sometimes I wonder if the kids are truly enjoying their activities. Agnes loves video games. I remember her playing Counterstrike in which she uses a gun to single-handedly engage ninety nine enemies who only had knives. I'm reading a book called Parallel Worlds written by physicist Kaku. When he was explaining the theories on a television show, promoting the book, it captured my imagination. It's a fascinating book which explores the science of time travel, wormholes, parallel universes and eleven dimensional hyperspace, subjects that engage numerous readers' interest around the world. I find the subject of black holes most engaging. It was an international bestseller for many months
